results.description:
Dynamic Figure Artists,

This is an open invite to the DRAW-A-THON at the High School of Art and Design, an epic 9-hour marathon of figure drawing with poses lasting from a few minutes up to six hours. Costumed superhero, sci-fi and fantasy models fill an all-ages area while a nude model section is open to anyone 18 or over (or minors accompanied by a parent/guardian consent form). Light refreshments and snacks will be available throughout the day and after admission you're free to come and go as you please.

Our own very talented Ed Velandria is an alum of the High School and one of the event's main organizers. DFD is not directly involved with organizing the event but many of us go every year and it's always a blast.

See you there!

Tickets and details:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/art-and-design-draw-a-thon-and-fundraiser-5-tickets-21118519059


General info:

Time:  10 a.m. to 7 p.m. 

The High School of Art & Design

245 East 56th Street, New York, NY

Tickets: $10+ (see event website)


Ed Velandria's work:

https://www.flickr.com/photos/nycsubwayseries/

Photos from past DRAW-A-THONs:

https://www.flickr.com/photos/107536353@N05/

http://www.artdesignalumni.com/category/drawathon/

This event is brought to you by the High School of Art and Design and the Art and Design Alumni Association.
results.name: Art and Design DRAW-A-THON 5

results.description:
REMEMBER: Please DO NOT RSVP here, but use the links in the description below to get your tickets. Meetup RSVPs will NOT be honored. This is not one of "our" events, but a fun afternoon and a good cause, and I know a lot of the members never miss this.

Hi everyone,
George Alonso here your VP of the High School of Art & Design Alumni Association.
Are you Ready!
EVENT REGISTRATION:
http://artdesigndrawathon5.eventbrite.com/

High School of Art & Design
Draw-A-Thon 5 and Fundraiser
Saturday March 19th
Time: 10:00am to 7:00 pm.

The Draw-A-Thon is a fundraiser where the proceeds go towards funding events for the students and other needs which may present themselves through out the school year.
Last years funds were used for the Fashion Style Show and the Spring Arts Festival.

CLASS YEAR MODEL SPONSORS
This Draw-A-Thon your donations will help sponsor models for the event which help off set our costs, and the upcoming Fashion Show and an Urban Arts Show. We normally have a group of about 12 professional models and student models. Cosplay models and Nudes.
Class years sponsoring our models at the last event was tremendously successful, We hope we can count on you again. Class years, individuals and companies will be acknowledged in all our print materials and recognized over a models station with a banner. All Fees collected at the door or online cover operating expenses and food with a portion also going to the school for student activities.

STORY
I would like to re- share a story with you.
last October I was at the school and was hearing how a couple of students could not afford to buy a sketch pad and I was heart broken. One of our goals has been to find a way to help students in need through out the year. This year the Class of 1989 has created an award for 9 freshmen students with simple needs such as picking up basic art supplies at the S.O Store.
"THANK YOU CLASS of 89" for paying it forward!
There are many students in need at Art & Design and your dollar support helps to make a difference in one's students life. Your award has sparked the creation of a much needed grant in the works

Donations can be made on line.

EVENT REGISTRATION:
http://artdesigndrawathon5.eventbrite.com/

The Alumni website/ donation page

If mailing a check:
Art and Design Alumni Association, Inc, PO Box 303, FDR Station, NYC NY[masked]


http://www.artdesignalumni.com/donation-form/

The Alumni website has a comment box.
Please note your class year and say if it's for model sponsoring.

Tickets in advance:
Students $10 Adults $20
Tickets at the door: Students $15 Adults $25
Currently Attending A&D High School Students Only $4.00 (Eventbrite fee included)
Middle School Student and Parent $10.00 in advance, $15 at the door
Middle school students interested in attending Art and Design are cordially invited to join us!
Bring your pencils and your art pads. Meet some of our staff, students and alumni. Middle school students must be accompanied by a paid parent/guardian who must stay with the student thoughout the event.
http://artdesigndrawathon5.eventbrite.com/

PLEASE LET US KNOW IF ANY QUESTIONS:

See you there.

results.description:
Have you even noticed how effective stories are at communicating and helping to influence people. Give people the facts, tell them your opinion and they don't always listen but tell them a story instead and it has more effect. You can be that person.


Joel

========================================

CLICK HERE: LEARN TO TELL YOUR STORY WITH IMPACT

========================================

Unleash your inner Story Teller! March 19 and 20, 2016 join Nick Kemp and Doug O’Brien in New York for…

Story-Telling from the "Outside Inn"

Join internationally known storytellers Nick Kemp and Doug O’Brien for their ever popular “Stories From the Outside Inn” workshop here in New York. It will be held on Saturday and Sunday, March 19 & 20, from 10 AM to 6 PM.

This is a story telling workshop. It is about how to write and how to deliver good stories effectively. This is a workshop for Corporate CEOs and this is a a workshop for Kindergarten teachers. This is a workshop for therapists and a workshop for salesmen. In short, this is a workshop for YOU! This workshop will help anybody get better at what they do because it will help you be a more effective communicator. It is fun. It is action packed. It is muti-media and chock full of invaluable learning and experience.

Discover how to write and tell YOUR story well – with fun and impact!

===================================

Sign up for our New York City class now!

Tuition for both days is $450@the door

====================================

Only $399 if you register before March 15th. Click Here Now!

=====================================

This is some of what will be included in the full weekend:

• The language of storytelling in change work

• The power of voice and tonality in exquisite communication

• Three classic Story arcs to help shape your stories in a compelling way

• Creating and using metaphors

• Neo Ericksonian language patterning

• Principles of improv

• much more…

“They say that everyone has a story to tell, and in this two day workshop, full of learning and laughter, Nick and Doug drew out wonderful stories from every single participant. The weekend is relevant to everyone, whether you’re new to writing stories or a seasoned author; whether public speaking makes you anxious or excited. I’ve come home with a new understanding of what works well and how to make it even better and I can’t wait to practice my new skills. A master class from two expert communicators.” – Jane James

===================================

Sign up for our New York City class now!

Tuition for both days is $450@the door

====================================

Only $399 if you register before March 15th.Click Here Now!

=====================================

You'll also have the chance to meet:

2 Seekers of Truth from ""Cosmic Health NYC - Meditation, Breathe, Spirit, Light""

3 Fans of Wellness from ""Holistic Wellness NYC - Outdoor, Yoga, Hiking, Mind, Body""

2 Somnambulists from ""Hypnosis and NLP Experience NYC""

1 Powerful Attractors from ""Law of Attraction NYC - Awaken Your Genie""

1 Powerful Creators from ""Self Empowerment NYC - Achieving Your Greatness""

1 Explorers of Health from "Alternative Health NYC"

1 MindBody Explorers from "Connecting Mind & Body NYC"

1 Radiant Energy Healers from "Energy Healers NYC"

2 Conquerers of Self-Doubt & Fear from "Gain Confidence NYC"

1 Explorers & Seekers from "Healers of Enlightenment & Transformation NYC"

A total of 10 people are expected to attend!

Edit Linking

results.description:
Section 2  is for new members with one or less meetups with our group.   Section 1 also announced is open to all members.  RSVP's begin Monday, March 7th at 8pm.

In honor of World Water Day which is March 22nd, join us on a “River-to-River” walk across Manhattan from the Hudson to the East River ending at beautiful Carl Schurz Park and Gracie Mansion.   The focus of this tour is the fact that New York City owes its history and development to its location and waterways! And NYC is blessed with having one of the best water systems of an large metropolitan area on the planet!  


We’ll also tell the story of the creation of Central Park and visit the site of a natural spring that was used by the residents of the Seneca Village community in the 1800’s!  This amazing stroll will cover the history of Upper Manhattan's development from the 1600’s to the present with stops at many architectural treasures, iconic buildings and extraordinary 5th Avenue mansions. 

This Meetup event entails 3-4 miles of walking.  Weather permitting, we'll take a picnic lunch break in Central Park and in any case bring what you wish to eat and plenty of water :) .

Here's a link with information about this years's World Water Day.

http://www.unwater.org/worldwaterday/about/en/


Cheers from Hank

[masked]

[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: #1, 2 or 3 subway to 72nd Street & Broadway, walk 2 blocks West
results.name: Section 2: World Water Day River-to-River Walk!  Upper West Side to East River

results.description:
**INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS**  

                               NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS!

         NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES 

                                      @ RIVERSIDE Park!

                             See our page on Facebook!:

                        ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQxq4zYJDFg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

We'll play 3 simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 108rd Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

results.description:
Here is a very cool hike, a wonderful scramble, a hike that is for the experienced hikers/scramblers only. There is a mile of rocky adventure which is not for beginners or those with improper footwear. So....experienced hikers only please. It is billed as 4 hours, 4.5 miles, strenuous by NYNJTC. This is one of my favorites.

From their description: This loop hike descends the Palisades cliffs, follows a challenging, rocky path along the Hudson River, passes a scenic waterfall, and climbs to reach a panoramic viewpoint over the river.

Scrambling is tricky stuff and sure footing is necessary for this. Please don't sign up if you've never hiked or scrambled before. 

Bring: Snacks, water, change of shirt/shoes, first aid kit, camera. Hiking shoes/boots mandatory. Grippy garden gloves for scrambling. 

We will follow the NYNJTC trip description for this at http://nynjtc.org/hike/giant-stairslong-path-loop-state-line-lookout

GPS coordinates for the State Line Lookout [masked],-73.907154.

Driving directions: If you are coming from the north on the Palisades Parkway, bear left just beyond Exit 3 and follow the signs for the State Line Lookout. Follow the access road for about half a mile until it ends at a large parking lot near the lookout. 

From the south take the Palisades Interstate Park north from the George Washington Bridge. Continue for 1.7 miles beyond Exit 2, and turn right at a sign for the State Line Lookout. 

We can carpool from 9W/Cornwall area at 9:15am. Email me if you want to carpool. We will dine afterwards. 

By signing up for or attending this event, you certify that you have read, understand and agree to the terms and conditions of the Orange County Outdoor Singles Liability Waiver (See "Liability Waiver" under the "Pages" tab above).

$2 Meetup fee unless you have over 50 adventures with me. WET ROCKS will very likely postpone things. Rain will definitely postpone. Check your emails for changes. Please send me your cell if I don't have it, I will return with mine. All hikes are at your own risk. SORRY, NO DOGS.
results.name: Giant Stairs/Long Path Loop!! SCRAMBLE!!!

results.description:
LEADER: Jeffrey Sovelove ([masked])

RATING: B 7 B

We will start at Sunrise Lake, then hike to the parking upper lot and back down to the lake using a combination of the Yellow and Red trails. The pace will be moderate to slow. See the Morris County Parks Commission website http://www.-morrisparks.org/aspparks/lmdir.asp for directions. Bring lots of water, lunch, and wear hiking boots. Meet in parking lot at 10 AM. Inclement weather cancels. Proper footgear required (stabilicers, crampons or snowshoes) if appropriate for the conditions. Joint ADK/Sierra Club hike.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance: Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

results.description:
A totally good excuse for those additional carbs you so crave, is the need for fuel now and during the upcoming season.  You don't want to bonk after all when you still have 10 miles to go on a ride!

 So we'll meet under the Arch at Prospect Park and do a lap before heading downhill for some pie and coffee at four and twenty blackbirds.  Now you can skip the pie and show up later, but I think you may need to evaluate your life priorities if you're going to pass on a piece of their pie!  Only about 5 miles here before we get some pie.

 After that we'll head to Manhattan via the WIlliamsburg Bridge, head down to the East side Greenway for a bit before entering Central Park at the SE corner and doing a lap. (If the day is extra nice and you'd rather skip the lap we can figure out a place to pick you up as you relax and take in the sunshine). After exiting at Columbus Circle we'll head down to the West side Greenway to the Village and head over to Father Demo Square.  Strategically located within walking distance to 3 great pizza places, Bleecker St Pizza, John's, and Joe's.  If we have enough folks we can get at least 1 pizza from each!   It's 20 miles of riding between the four and twenty and the pizza places.  We'll place some orders at the right time so when we get there the pies will be ready.

 After that it's 6 miles back to Prospect Park.

Cue sheet             https://goo.gl/j2vFLl

Please join FluidBiDesign / MenKIND and Black Men Exchange (BMX) at Brooklyn's MoCADA Museum during the weekend of March 19th-20th 2016.

This is a FREE 2 -day gathering, where we invite ALL our Bi-identified and SGL (Same Gender-Loving) Men of African Descent to gather together. Great food and beverages will be served. Along with good fellowship. 

A central goal of 'Breaking Bread' is education, affirmation, healing, and legacy building. We look forward in seeing you all there.

PLEASE REGISTER at [masked] to reserve your spot while spaces are available. Bring a friend!

For more information please visit www.bmxnational.org or send your inquires to [masked]

_________________________________________

FluidBiDesign is envisioned as a advocacy group and a community for Bisexual Men of African Descent who conceive of their identity (inclusive of their sexuality, but not limited to) as "fluid".

The purpose is to create forum for the study and exchange of ideas, a safe and supportive space for the sharing of personal experiences related to negotiating our lives within a fluid context, and a community of like minded creative individuals interested in both raising and broadening the level of discussion around identity, manhood, and masculinity....

They say "if you build it they will come"... Looking for a similarly minded brothas, fluid by design and by choice, to build this with me...

The Hispanic Society of America was founded as a free museum and research library in 1904. It constitutes the most extensive collection of Hispanic art and literature outside of Spain and Latin America. The museum collection includes paintings, decorative arts, archaeology and sculpture; housed in a Beaux-Arts Building on Audubon Terrace.

We will begin by walking around the entry courtyard before entering the building and exploring the collection and taking photographs of the displays that appeal to us.

Please RSVP as soon as possible. If there are more than ten of us we need to make a reservation with the Society.


No tripods are allowed in the museum under any circumstances.

results.description:
Updated December 18th, 2015


WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 


[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

[img src="">

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

results.description:
Join us for March's book club brunch at Uptown 596 in Montclair for a fun get together and great discussion!

This month's book is: The Life We Bury by Allen Eskens Book Summary/Overview: College student Joe Talbert has the modest goal of completing a writing assignment for an English class. His task is to interview a stranger and write a brief biography of the person. With deadlines looming, Joe heads to a nearby nursing home to find a willing subject. There he meets Carl Iverson, and soon nothing in Joe's life is ever the same. Carl is a dying Vietnam veteran--and a convicted murderer. With only a few months to live, he has been medically paroled to a nursing home, after spending thirty years in prison for the crimes of rape and murder. As Joe writes about Carl's life, especially Carl's valor in Vietnam, he cannot reconcile the heroism of the soldier with the despicable acts of the convict. Joe, along with his skeptical female neighbor, throws himself into uncovering the truth, but he is hamstrung in his efforts by having to deal with his dangerously dysfunctional mother, the guilt of leaving his autistic brother vulnerable, and a haunting childhood memory. Thread by thread, Joe unravels the tapestry of Carl’s conviction. But as he and Lila dig deeper into the circumstances of the crime, the stakes grow higher. Will Joe discover the truth before it’s too late to escape the fallout?

I look forward to seeing you all at March's event!

Moderate-Strenuous hike offers a little bit of everything. We will take in the views from Claudius Smith Rock, tackle the Elbow Brush rock scramble (which can be bypassed for less experienced hikers) and descend Pound Mountain via Almost Perpendicular. Several small stream crossings will require everyone to wear waterproof hiking boots. Bring a snack/lunch and at least 2 liters of water.
Pace will be relaxed and will take approx 4 hours to complete.

The group will meet at the Tuxedo train station commuter parking lot located on East Village Rd at 10:30AM.

[masked],[masked]

Follow N.J. Route 17 North to the New York State Thruway and take Exit 15A (Sloatsburg). Turn left at the bottom of the ramp onto N.Y. Route 17 North, and continue for 4.9 miles, passing through the villages of Sloatsburg and Tuxedo. Just past the Tuxedo railroad station, turn right onto East Village Road, cross the tracks, and turn left into a commuter parking lot (free parking on weekends).

results.description:
This is a hike for parents/families with young children. This hike is absolutely alcohol-free. 

Before joining this event, please: 1. fill out your profile - at least answer yes/no to the questions there. 2. read the details further. 

Приглашаем семьи с маленькими детьми, от 0 до 7 лет, которые ездят на родителях в рюкзаках или ходят сами, прогуляться вокруг Ramapo Lake.


По дороге можно посмотреть на каменную башню и руины.


Недалеко от NYC.

Протяженность маршрута 4-5 миль. По желанию можно будет удлинить, рядом много другая маршрутов.

Сложность невысокая.

Ходим медленно - около 1.7 миль в час.

Ближе к концу маршрута можно будет устроить длинный привал с едой. Короткие остановки будем делать по ходу по мере необходимости.

С собой:

Достаточное количество воды/питья. Сейчас тепло, пить хочется. Лучше брать по 2 литра на взрослого и по литру на ребенка.

Можно брать чай в термосах.

Еда для перекуса.

Аптечка первой помощи - лекарства, которые вам могут понадобиться, пластырь, бинтик.

Детям:

Панама/косынка/бандана от солнца.

Одежда по погоде (не слишком теплая - при ходьбе жарко) + что-то с собой теплое + что-то от дождя.

Ноги должны быть закрыты от насекомых, растительности итп!

Руки, желательно, тоже (в зависимости от погоды).

Носки не слишком низкие (должны перекрываться со штанами).

Обувь - удобная, с хорошей подошвой, и лучше с поддержкой лодыжки (ботинки).

По всем вопросам пишите комментарии сюда, Private Messages Марине, или звоните по выходным и по вечерам с 8 до 11 по тел.732-7898224.

This will be a guided tour (with much commentary) of the Wall Street area.  We will make our way up Broadway and cross over the Brooklyn Bridge.  Then we will explore the many waterfront parks that line the Brooklyn side of the East River, and walk the length of the Promenade.  The tour will end on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights where there are many restaurants available for a late lunch.

We will be walking at a moderate (not slow pace) and there will be many restrooms stops along the way.  The walk will last about five hours and will cover 6 miles.  From the endpoint of the walk on Montague Street, the nearest Subway station is the one at Court Street-Borough Hall (2,3,4,5 and the R train)

Heavy rain or extreme cold will cancel the walk, check this site for updates.

DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER

Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown: 

1. Play safe,  games are 7v7 including goalie, NO slide tackles, excessive aggression will NOT be tolerated (the precinct is across the street...LOL!!).  

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St.with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street. 

5. HAVE FUN!

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. results.description:
THIS CLASS IS FULL, BUT YOU CAN STILL JOIN THE WAITLIST AT www.tinkergarten.com

Come join us for a free trial of Tinkergarten's outdoor learning classes. If you are excited to sign up for a season of Tinkergarten, our trial class will give you the chance to see, first hand, what a class feels like and how we inspire authentic, play-based learning for children (and a great time for all)! This free trial class is designed to be the first class in the Spring season of Tinkergarten. This class is designed for children 18 months through five years old and a treasured adult.

Tinkergarten classes are based on a progressive curriculum comprised of our blueprint activities. The curriculum for each class is tailored to the ages and prior knowledge of kids, and are appropriate for the geographic region and season of the class. Leaders further tailor classes to meet the needs of the individuals and artfully facilitate the activity to maximize the fun and the learning for all involved. Below is a sampling of the types of activities to expect in this class.


SAMPLE ACTIVITY - MAGIC PETAL POTIONS
Skills: Creativity, Imagination, Behavioral Schema, Sensory
For petal potions, kids put water and anything from nature into a jar and mix it up, just like we did when we were kids. Making potions never gets old, and if done with some finesse, it helps kids develop creativity, imagination, sensory skills and several universal ways to encourage brain development known as behavioral schema. Although we call it magic “petal potion,” you can make magic potion anytime of year with any natural ingredients.

SAMPLE ACTIVITY - KINGS AND QUEENS OF WILD THINGS
Skills: Creativity, Imagination, Behavioral Schema, Fine Motor, Self Esteem
Combine the magic of Maurice Sendak's "Wild Things" with the power of double-sided tape to turn a day outdoors into a brain-boosting, unforgettable, wild rumpus!

SPACE IS LIMITED. RSVP at http://tkgtn.com/m9xwm TO CLAIM A SPOT.

Join us as Arteum Goncharov (co-founder & CEO) gives a talk on MarsPolar via LiveStream from Russia. MarsPolar is a private crowd-sourced initiative, which aims to research and plan the establishment of a human colony on Mars.

Come watch this LiveStream with us at NYIT, ask your questions to Arteum and network with everyone afterwards. 

This #SpaceTalk can also be freely viewed on LiveStream.com:

• https://livestream.com/accounts/42333/mars-polar-spacetalk

MarsPolar is an extremely fast growing international group of space enthusiasts, scientists, engineers, designers and dreamers, who plan to work to push the boundaries of space exploration. We are working to establish connections with researchers, scientists, space agencies and private space companies. Then we intend to dedicate specialized teams to try and work on specific problems, that help us reach closer to the dream of establishing a settlement on Mars.

Agenda 

1. Introduction
2. History and description of Marspolar project
3. Goals and Current objectives
4. Research directions


-Landing site

-Situation of Radiation during spaceflight and on the planet. Solar particle event and Galactic Cosmic Rays protection options.

-Magnetic field of Mars and local magnetization of landing site

-Plant growth

5. Answering questions

Learn more about MarsPolar on their website at:

• http://marspolar.space/
results.how_to_find_us: NYIT Incubator. Fourth floor conference room at the end of the hall. and on LiveStream.com, see below:
results.name: MarsPolar, a international Mars Exploration Initiative #SpaceTalk

results.description:
ALL MET TOURS ARE SOLD OUT. IF YOU DIDN'T ALREADY PAY FOR A TICKET, PLEASE DON'T COME.

OUT PROFESSIONALS INVITES YOU TO ENJOY AN EYE-OPENING PRIVATE TOUR OF THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART, WHERE HOMOEROTICA HANGS IN PLAIN SIGHT.

On Saturday, March 19, Members and friends of Out Professionals meet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a private tour of homoerotic treasures from the permanent collection, conducted by Classicist and art historian Andrew Lear.

Our tour explores some of the Met's prize homoerotica, from ancient Greek nudes and erotic vase-painting to works from the Renaissance and the present day, many expressing same-gender desire. Famous artists and subjects appear, but so do lesser-known artists and works whose homoerotic charge is often ignored, including phallic totems from the Met’s Oceania collection.

Near “Portrait of a German Officer” (above right), a monumental painting by Marsden Hartley memorializing his lover, who died at 24, is “Gertrude Stein” (above left) the famous writer and expatriate, as painted by Pablo Picasso. And then there’s “The Horse Fair,” by the French artist Rosa Bonheur, who portrayed herself dressed as a man because women were barred from such events.

Andrew Lear has taught art history and Classics at Harvard, Columbia and NYU. Born in Dublin, he is the founder of Oscar Wilde Tours, the first company to offer tours focused on LGBT history. For Lear’s insights on just one of the works included in our tour, visit The Gay and Lesbian Review.

WHAT’S UP

Private midday tour of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, highlighting masterpieces with backstories of particular interest to an LGBT audience. Tour is limited to 20 persons, departs promptly at 11 a.m. and lasts approximately two hours. Your ticket admits you to the Met’s galleries, cafe and store until 9 p.m.

WHERE 


The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street. Subway: 4/5 to 86th Street, 6 to 77th Street. Ascend the main staircase and gather inside, just to the right, near the coat check. Operated by Oscar Wilde Tours, this event is not an official Met offering.

ADMISSION

 Please print and pocket a copy of your online receipt. Met Member or student: Met or student ID is required for museum entry. No walk-ins.
results.name: Let's Meetup and See Homoerotic Art at the Met!

Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at [masked]

You probably ride the NYC subways every week but did you know that before the subways we had miles of elevated tracks in the city? Did you know the very first subway was a pneumatic tube that stretched only a few hundred feet and did you know that the original Penn Station was bigger and more beautiful than Grand Central??    Our tours are designed for people who live, work and play in New York.  We give you an opportunity to see the city that surrounds you every day in a totally different light! Join a few dozen fun and friendly people for this journey back in time!The group will meet across from Grand Central then you will enjoy a brief tour of  Grand Central then hop on the subway to see some other very cool sights that you probably have walked past a hundred times and never realized.

Some of the things you will see along the way:

-Grand Central then and now.

-The ghosts stations at 18th and City Hall (ride through)

-Excavated walls, tile and artwork at 14th street.

-Amazing remnants of the old Penn Station.

-The city's oldest token booth

You will also see fantastic pictures of the subway from its beginning to the famous graffiti cars of the 80's.

Can I come alone?  Yes 98% of those attending will likely come on their own

How long will it take?  Start to finish about 3 hours.

How much does it cost? $15 for the tour and you will likely have to swipe your metrocard 2-3 times.

What should I wear? Winter casual.

The tour ends at Penn Station

PLEASE BRING EXACT CHANGE
results.name: NY Tours For New Yorkers: NYC Subways & Stations History

results.description:
Hello Everypony. Its a new year and Its time for a new museum. Next stop, The Intrepid Museum.

This museum is on an aircraft carrier, called the Intrepid. This ship did its duty during the WWII and the Vietnam. Now it serves as a historic landmark showcasing lots of historic war planes, and some space crafts including the Enterprise and the Pavilion. Also on sight is the Growler, a submarine which we can walk through.

Prices:

$24 for admission to the Intrepid and the Growler.

$31 for the Space Shuttle, the Intrepid, and the Growler

Of course we will discuss on what we will be doing and what we wan to see when we all arrive. 


Keep in mind it will be on water so if you're prone to getting seasick there are over the counter medicine for that. The day may be cold, near freezing, so keep checking the temperature and dress accordingly.

Any question just PM me or text me at 3four7 four1seven 2four2one. 

Hope to see ya there.
results.name: Bronies Visit Museum #2

results.description:
How is time like a temperature?  Discover the deep and fascinating connection between the theory of fundamental particles, and the theory which describes bulk matter. The two theories are connected by the Path Integral.

We will follow up...or rather stay back from...last week's presentation from Amol on Renormalization. We will start with the Ising Model of Spin Magnetization and discuss its behavior near critical points.  Attention will focus on correlations...correlation functions...correlation lengths, scaling and universality.

Hope to see you there!

Some really good reads...

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model


http://www.fulviofrisone.com/attachments/article/483/030818090032%20An%20Introduction%20To%20Lattice%20Gauge%20Theory%20And%20Spin%20Systems.pdf


http://arxiv.org/pdf/hep-th/9403084v2.pdf


http://www.springer.com/cda/content/document/cda_downloaddocument/9783642331046-c2.pdf?SGWID=0-0-45-1353008-p174605333
results.name: The Connection Between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics

This is it -- your *NEW* regularly-occurring opportunity to get more hands-on time hacking F#!

We'll be featuring a coding dojo every month (and in time we might transition to progressive development projects). But it's also an open invite for anything and everything F#. Want to contribute to some great open-source F# projects? C'mon down! Want to gather feedback on an upcoming presentation topic? That's cool, too. Simply want to discuss F# code with other like-minded individuals? Gotcha covered.

We'll be meeting for 5 hours on a Saturday in DUMBO (that's in Brooklyn, for those of you in Jersey). So, feel free to only drop in for a little while, or stay the entire time.

*Note: dojo's will be run from noon until 3 PM.*

We'll provide internet and electricity (and maybe even snacks). You bring a laptop, a power cord, and a desire to code! Let's do this.

(Big thanks to the New York Foundation for the Arts for the use of their awesome space!)

results.description:
This week we wrap up our exploration of mindfulness and look at how we can take it from the cushion into regular daily life.  

Staying with Jon Kabat-Zinn’s definition of mindfulness as being "awareness that arises through paying attention, on purpose, in the present moment, non-judgmentally” we see nothing is excluded from mindful awareness.  So, we just have to turn everyday activities and experiences into moments of mindfulness.We can notice we’re caught up in things and remember to come back to ourselves – take a breath, take a moment, find that space where we can see more fully and clearly and see where we have options and choice.

• We can notice our body is sharing important feedback and turn our full attention there.

• We can notice emotions arising and see if they’re a response to direct experience or a reaction to a story or judgments we’ve created around the experience.

•  We can notice our mind has wandered or we’ve become lost in thought and remember that we don’t have to get mired in the content of thoughts if they take us away from direct experience in this moment. 

•  And we can notice how our general state of mind is influencing everything with which we interact and find skillful ways to open to a broader, more inclusive viewpoint. 

Mindfulness is an important strategy that helps create the environment we need to be kinder, more compassionate and generous with ourselves and others.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.


Foundations of Mindfulness - Introduction

Mindfulness is more than just paying attention. It is powered by intention, but we also have to get out of our own way to experience clearly what’s actually appearing. We have to find an openness of heart and mind and suspend our judgements and theories and rationales so we can see more than what we always see. We have to begin to relinquish the "I" and "mine" kinds of ownership over what arises in our experience. We also have to unhook from the time line that may bind us to the past or project us to the future and be mindful now.

Over the next few weeks we will explore of the traditional Foundations of Mindfulness.

Introduction to Mindfulness
Mindfulness of the Breath
Mindfulness of the Body
Mindfulness of Emotions
Mindfulness of Thinking
Mindfulness of the Mind
Mindfulness in Daily Life
results.name: Foundations of Mindfulness in Daily Life

results.description:
This is an open house and introduction to Lyndhurst Meditation. This introduction gives hope for those seeking happiness, peace, and truth.

At Lyndhurst Meditation we use a very simple, yet direct way of cleansing and freeing the mind. This meditation is a customized guided one-on-one practice through self-reflection.

Give your mind and heart a break from the chaos of everyday life! Deeply examine and empty your self to find absolute peace and freedom!

If you are interested in becoming a member of our meditation center we will offer a special discounted price for meetup members only! 

We are located at 306 Ridge Rd, Lyndhurst, NJ 07071. Our meditation center is located across the stress from Wendy's. You can park in the front and additional free parking is located in the rear of the building. This introduction will last about an hour to an hour and a half. If you have many plans for the day please say this before the meetup starts so we can accommodate you properly. 

**If you are not able to attend this event, but have an interest in Lyndhurst Meditation you can call our center to have a personal introduction today! Lyndhurst Meditation is a non-profit organization and is tax deductible. A $10 donation is appreciated for the introduction.

results.description:
This event was posted on the First Time Upper West Side moms group, but since it is on the weekend, I am reposting it here:

Symphony Space is offering the FTUWSmoms discounted tickets and group seating for their kids show Moon Mouse: A Space Odyssey. This show is for ages 4 & up. (Please note: the show is performed in a darkened theater.) 

Plus, the nearby diner Big Daddy's is offering us 20% off meals. So anyone who wants can also meet up after the show. I will try to make reservations for anyone who wants to go to lunch afterwards. 

Also, anyone who buys tickets can get a code to download songs from[masked] season "Just Kidding" musicians. Here are the details:


Saturday, March 19th at 11 am
Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway (at 95th Street; across from 96th/B'way station).
Event link: http://www.symphonyspace.org/event/8972/Dance-Family-Theatre/just-kidding-lightwire-theater-moon-mouse-a-space-odyssey

Our ticket price is $15 (use the code " FTUWS " at checkout. ABOUT THE SHOW:

Following up on their blockbuster "Dino-Light" show, Lightwire Theater presents a musical glow-in-the-dark adventure tale that celebrates differences. Marvin the mouse craves popularity, but the “cool” rats think he’s just a nerd. To escape their taunts, he dives into a world of fantasy where he flies to the moon on a homemade rocket, meets a cast of misfit creatures, and learns a valuable lesson about celebrating difference. But most of the fun comes from Lightwire Theatre’s eye-popping visuals, in which puppets that are seemingly drawn on a darkened stage with electroluminescent wire take on personalities as vibrant and inspiring as their exteriors

LUNCH AT BIG DADDY'S:

Nearby family-friendly restaurant Big Daddy's (2454 Broadway, at 91st - http://bigdaddysnyc.com) offers FTUWS Moms Meetup 20 percent off all meal purchases on Saturday, March 19th. Discount vouchers will be available to ticket holders for the "Moon Mouse" show, or guests may mention code :[masked] at the restaurant to obtain 20 percent off your bill (guests must inform server upon ordering food).

FREE SONG DOWNLOADS: Get a link to download songs from[masked] season "Just Kidding" musicians (Joanie Leeds, Elizabeth Mitchell, Justin Roberts, The Pop Ups, Gustafer Yellowgold and more top recording artists). Simply send Beth (Beth B-C at [masked]) a message after you order tickets, and Beth will send the download link!

Do you have questions or suggestions? Please email Beth B-C at [masked]

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Dining and Museum

Part 1: Flushing Food Crawl + Amazing Indian Temple

DESCRIPTION: Let's do a Flushing Food Crawl. We will be making multiple stops at several small restaurants and vendors in Flushing to try specific snack food items originated from Korean, Northern Chinese, Sichuanese, and Southern Indian cuisines.

First Stop: White Bear,[masked] Roosevelt Ave, Flushing, NY 11354

We will meet and make our first stop at White Bear to try Sichuanese spicy wontons.

Second Stop: Tianjin Xianbing, 41-28 Main St, Flushing, NY 11355

We will make our second stop at Tianjin Xianbing to try Tianjin-style meat pies (天津餡餅).

Third Stop: Sheng Jin Eatery, 41-40 Main St, Flushing, NY 11354

We will make our third stop at Sheng Jin Eatery to try Northern Chinese omelette (煎餅果子) and Rolling Donkey (驢打滾). Here's some info on these dishes:

Jianbing, a traditional snack/meal that’s often eaten for breakfast, is a fried crepe made from a batter of wheat and grain flour that is fried on a griddle with an egg(s) and can be topped with scallions, baocui (薄脆 a kind of crispy fried cracker) and cilantro. It can be thick, thin, crispy or chewy, but it’s almost always folded several times before serving.

煎餅餜子是起源於天津市的一種以麵糊攤製成煎餅、再於餅上打入雞蛋攤開、後捲起再裹入脆餅等食材及調料作成的街頭小吃，在各地改良後流行，主要用作早餐。

Rolling Donkeys are steamed glutinous rice rolls filled with red bean paste or brown sugar that is then rolled and covered in a soybean flour crumble. Its origins can be traced to the Qing Dynasty. The cake, which has a yellowish color, is sweet and a little sticky, with a very nice bean flavor.

驢打滾，又稱豆麵糕，是一種以糯米做皮，紅豆做餡的滿族傳統小吃，清朝時列為宮廷食品，現已成為北京著名小吃。因為在其表面裹有均勻的一層豆麵，外觀頗似小毛驢在土地上打滾後渾身沾滿干土而得名。

驢打滾的製作是將糯米麵和成米漿，上鍋蒸熟成麵團，然後用勁攪拌，再裹以炒熟的豆麵擀成麵皮，放入紅豆餡捲成卷，切成合適的大小即可。

Fourth Stop: Ganesh Temple, 45-57 Bowne St, Flushing, NY 11355

We will make a stop at an Indian Temple nearby right before we make our fifth stop. I am not sure whether we will be able to go inside but at least we will look around outside and take some pictures.

Fifth Stop: Dosa Hutt, 45-63 Bowne St, Flushing, NY 11355


We will make our fifth stop at Dosa Hutt to try Dosa and Uttapam. Here's some info on these dishes:

Dosa is a fermented crepe made from rice batter and black lentils. It is a staple dish in South Indian states of Tamil nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala and Telangana. It is also popular in other parts of India, and other countries like Sri Lanka, Mauritius, Myanmar, Nepal, Bangladesh, Malaysia and Singapore.

Uttapam is a dosa-like dish made from the same batter. Unlike a dosa, which is crisp and unlike relatively soggy crepes, it is a thick pancake mostly topped with diced onions, tomatoes, cilantro or cheese. Uttapam is sometimes characterized as an Indian pizza.


Last Stop: Kimganae, 3912 Union St, Flushing, NY 11354

We will make our last stop at Kimganae to try Kimbap rolls.

Path of Food Crawl:

Part 2: Explore Queens Museum

DESCRIPTION: The Queens Museum, formerly the Queens Museum of Art, is an art museum and educational center located in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in the borough of Queens in New York City, United States. The museum is housed in the New York City Building, which was built for the 1939 New York World's Fair, and which then hosted the United Nations General Assembly from 1946 to 1950. The museum itself was founded in 1972, and has, among its permanent exhibitions, the Panorama of the City of New York, a scale model of the five boroughs built for the 1964 New York World's Fair.

The Queens Museum has focused on outreach and access for a wide range of audiences, and is known for international contemporary art exhibitions that reflect the cultural diversity of the borough. The museum’s Education Department is the first in America to employ art therapists in a dedicated, fully accessible classroom, while the Public Events department has hired community organizers to work on local improvement initiatives. The Queens Museum is, in addition to a fine arts collecting museum, also a historical site, community center, and educational classroom.

DISCLAIMER:
When you RSVP "Yes" to an event, or participate in an event, please understand that you are responsible for your own safety and well-being, and will hold no one else liable in case of personal injury or any mishap. You agree not to hold the meetup group's organizer, assistant organizers, event organizers, hosts, or any other group members responsible for any injuries or issues that may occur at any time before, during or after an event. You are personally responsible for obtaining essential information about an event, making necessary preparations for participating in the event, and ensuring your own safety and well-being. Your RSVP of "Yes" on the event page or attendance of an event signifies your full understanding and acceptance of the terms of this liability waiver. We reserve the rights to limit this event to physically fit people.

END
results.name: Flushing Food Crawl + Amazing Indian Temple + Explore Queens Museum

results.description:
MUST Register Here to Attend!


On March 19th, Golden Gate University Adjunct Professor Roman Bogomazov will present an all-day online workshop on Intraday Trading with the Wyckoff Method. Though this approach to the markets works well on any time frame, Wyckoff himself found it to be exceptionally profitable for day-trading. In Roman’s prior workshops on Swing Trading with the Wyckoff Method, students have requested that he present an additional session focused specifically on intra-day trades. This is that course!


This day-long workshop, designed for intermediate to advanced traders, includes:
• Pre-trade routines:
o How to select the best trade candidates based on analysis of their daily swing, trend and overall market structure
o Pre-open comparative strength analysis for stock trades
• Tactics for trade entry and management, including points of entry, initial stop-loss orders and Wyckoff-type exits
• Switching timeframes from intraday entries to longer-term swing positions to boost reward-to-risk ratios
• Illustrative case studies of intraday trades of stocks, E-minis and currencies


Participants in Roman’s prior swing trading workshops wrote glowing testimonials:
“Roman thinks out of the box…His explanations are clear and the information is so helpful. I believe in mastery…Roman’s analysis helps me so much on this path.”
"Brilliant analysis! Roman is terrific in explaining what the market is doing and where individual stocks are (probably) going.”


To ensure an optimal learning environment, this workshop will be limited to no more than 25 students. Reserve your place and receive a discounted registration fee by signing up now!


When: Saturday, March 19, 2015, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m., including a break for lunch
Cost: $795
Discounts for participants registering before March 12th:
Regular enrollment - $695
Current AWTC and WTPC students - $595
results.name: ONLINE WORKSHOP: Intraday Trading Using the Wyckoff Method

results.description:
Hello, My Name Is Doris (R)
Sally Field, Max Greenfield - 1 hr. 35 mins. 

When Doris Miller meets John Fremont, her company's hip new art director, sparks fly-at least for Doris.

In the cluttered house she shared with her late mother, Doris mines the Internet for information on her one-and-only, guided by the 13-year-old granddaughter of her best pal Roz. When Doris begins showing up at John's regular haunts, she wins over his Williamsburg friends. Her new life brings Doris a thrilling perspective, but also creates a rift between her and her longtime friends and family, who believe she's making a fool of herself over a guy half her age. Eager for all the experiences she has missed out on, Doris throws caution to the wind and follows her heart for the very first time.

results.description:
JOIN US AND MARCH WITH THE ROCKVILLE CENTRE TEA PARTY IN THE ANNUAL ROCKVILLE CENTRE ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE ON SATURDAY, MARCH 19th at 11:30 AM

We meet in the RVC Municipal Parking Lot

PLEASE RSVP TODAY TO MARCH WITH OUR GROUP IN THIS YEAR'S  ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE!

Please join with the Rockville Centre Tea Party Patriots to march together in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade. We invite members from all local Tea Party groups, your family, friends, and children of all ages to join us. EVERYONE IS WELCOME TO JOIN US!

Join us for an afternoon celebration! This will be the seventh time we all gather behind a TEA PARTY BANNER and march in the ROCKVILLE CENTRE ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE! Our objective is to assemble and march together in solidarity as ONE TEA PARTY GROUP. You need not be Irish, nor from Rockville Centre. We will be showing our respect and love for the traditions of our nation and displaying our colors proudly.

We request that you bring an American, Irish, or Gadsden flag. We ask that you DO NOT bring any political, or any other signs, and to dress respectfully to set an example of a Patriotic American Organization. Green is the color of the day! We have a limited number of free green caps for anyone marching with us. We also have plenty of assorted flags that you are welcome to borrow for the duration of the parade should you need one.

The RVC St Patrick's Day Parade charity has been raising money for three different charities each year in it's 20 years of operation, and has raised over $978,000 for 55 different and well deserved charities overall. It's the "Parade that Cares and Shares." The RVC Police ask that there be NO open beverages in the streets or in the Parade. There is also NO literature or brochures of any kind  allowed to be handed out.

All are welcome to march with our Tea Party group. Bring your whole family and all of your friends. Last year we had over 40 marchers, including several vehicles, and a piper and drummer. This year we are aiming for 60 or more participants! Let's show the spectators that the Tea Party is still a huge, united force. We look forward to seeing you all there.

                          PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE RSVP TO THIS EVENT!!


**********************************************************************
results.name: MARCH WITH THE RVC TEA PARTY IN THE ANNUAL RVC ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE  3/19/16

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Welcome to the happiest day party in New York City! The Festival of Colors celebrates the coming of spring, the joy of friendship, and equality for all. This Indian Festival happens every year, not only in India but throughout the world. Join us on March 19th or March 26th. This is a day event and all nationalities and ethnicities are encouraged to participate!

Make sure to wear white because this party gets colorful. The colored powders used in Holi represent happiness, love, and the freedom to live vibrantly. Take the opportunity to cover yourself and your friends in colorful powders and dance your heart out. Enjoy musical performances, delicious food, and an afternoon of messy, color fun! 

Tickets for March 19th - http://www.eventbrite.com/e/holi-in-the-city-brunch-holi-party-march-19-festival-of-colors-holi-hai-tickets-20438940421?aff=HOLI319&afu=133842352783

results.description:
Here's a video from our last performance; "Santa Baby"


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Eq5zNQPuFw

This Season we are playing The Beatles!

We have done Classic Rock, The Rolling Stones, Reggae, Motown, Summer Songs, Fleetwood Mac, Funk and Christmas ensembles, The Beatles is certainly due in our selection!

Acoustic guitars, bass and ukeleles welcome. If electric bring a portable amp:)


This ensemble welcomes ALL LEVELS, so pick your part and let's play! 

To join:

• RSVP before you attend the session.

• Choose your guitar part from TAB>MORE>FILES download/print and bring it to practice to follow. (check by 12/30) 

• Bring acoustic guitar or electric with a portable amp. 

• Have an amazing time!

Practice days are:

Every Saturday 12-2pm starting January 9th til April 23rd, the day before the performance, 16 practice sessions.

Season Pass

You can purchase the Season Pass (16 sessions at discount + $30 show fee) for $380  (you save $50 on practice sessions)

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=MWF56937BM6Q8


Show Day is Sunday, May 1st at 2pm

The show will be at Arlene's Grocery in the East Village April 24th at 1pm(soundcheck) and doors at 2pm. Arlene's is an awesome show venue with professional stage, sound and lights, everyone will be miked or amplified. If you are coming to rehearsal with a portable amp you should also bring it to the venue.

We will have a drummer and a singer TBA.

There will be tickets for this show, they can be purchase before hand at $5 or at the door for $10.

There is a show fee of $30 for each ensemble member that will go toward venue, sound engineer and hired musicians costs.

Arlene's Grocery is strictly 21+ and no children will be allowed at the show even if they are accompanied by the parent, I'm sorry:( :(

There are two bars on site and lots of food spots and great restaurants in the area for before or after the show.

All you need is love and some Beatles!

Check out our website at http://edelage.wix.com/edge

results.description:
Surviving as an artist in the modern age is tricky. With a little bit of strategy and discipline, you can survive—and even thrive—as an artist and creator.
"Thrive As An Artist", a Financial Literacy Workshop for Artists, has partnered with Mike Geffner Presents The Inspired Word to host a THREE-part event where Artists can perform at our Open Mic and learn how to thrive financially!
Each workshop will be run by a financial expert ready to help artists learn how to save and budget for their dreams!
*****
NO COVER & ALL AGES
RSVP required to Attend.
Dates: 3/19, 4/9 & 4/23.
Doors open @ 11:30am
Open Mic Signup @ 12:00pm
Performances & Workshop begins: 1:00pm
Where: Capital One 360 Café - 968 3rd Avenue
Manhattan, New York 10022
*****
Coffee and snacks will be provided.
*****
Performance slots are limited so if you are looking to participate in the Open Mic we STRONGLY suggest you arrive early to guarantee your performance slot as this Open Mic will be first come first serve. To create a PG environment all material must be clean and radio friendly. There is limited space for this workshop, so RSVP's are required.
*****
Backline Provided: Yamaha PA, Three Shure Mics, Alesis QS7 Keyboard & a Roland Jazz Guitar Amp.
*****
Directions By Subway: Take the 4,5,6,N,Q,R to 59th St & Lexington. The Cafe is located on the corner of E 58th & 3rd Avenue.
results.name: Thrive As An Artist: An Open Mic & Financial Lit Workshop

venue.name: Inside the entrance to the NYC Fire Museum

results.description:
We'll start by visiting the NYC Fire Museum, featuring paintings, photographs, wagons, uniforms, ornate helmets, and equipment from the past three centuries. Then we'll tour several art galleries, some strange (but soothing) art installations, a biological artifacts shop, and some architectural highlights of this historic neighborhood. And we'll stop for lunch (see below). If you'd prefer to skip the museum, you can meet us in the lobby or outside as we're leaving,  at around 12:50 PM. 


PLEASE READ THESE DETAILS, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED:

DISTANCE: About 2 miles

PACE: Moderate (3 blocks in 4 minutes), NOT SLOW. Sorry, I do not enjoy walking slowly and I will not wait for stragglers.

COST: $5 for the museum (reduced group rate), and $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee. 

LUNCH: Bring your own or buy it at or near the lunch stop, a theater cafe that sells $8 sandwiches. Lunch will be around 2 PM.

ENDING TIME: Around 5 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

TRANSPORTATION: C, E train to Spring St. (uptown only), or 1 train to Houston or Canal St. For details, consult mta.tripplanner.org, Google Transit (maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html) and/or a subway map, since those sites do not always list the ideal routes. 

WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient. The list will shrink or disappear by the morning of the walk, due to cancellations and no-shows, especially at the last minute. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up. And don't worry about big crowds--the number who actually show up is generally 35 to 55, no matter how many are signed up or waiting. 

One of the museum's many old fire engines:

https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSz-aHkU4cO0lrMhH3OgkIx9KpIZxYUzuzE2Bc6cBuR7CQf9KkQ0Q

** In order to support Cobblestones for letting us use their space, there is a $15 minimum food/drink order per person.**

**Please note that this is at a different venue than the Tuesday night meetups.**

Once again, it's time for our monthly weekend meetup where we tend to stay longer & play more games than our weekly get-together. The next one will be on Saturday March 19.

Join us for our awesome Weekend Boardgaming Meetup at Cobblestone's pub! We start around noon & usually stay until the early evening. We're a friendly group of gamers that play everything from Codenames & Ticket to Ride to Dead of Winter & Agricola! Everyone is welcome - all ages (must be over 21) but must be young at heart!

If you don't recognize the games, don't worry, everyone is happy to teach new players the rules. And feel free to bring your own board games if you wish. Between all of us, there's usually a large selection of games to choose from.

If you're looking for a chill, fun way to spend a Saturday afternoon - come join us!

In order to support our awesome, not-too-loud, well-lit venue, each person must purchase something to eat or a few drinks.
**Again, there is a $15 minimum per person.**

We look forward to seeing you there!

We also have a Facebook group.  Everyone in the Meetup is welcome.  Just click the link and ask to join.  Someone will add you once they can.

Forest Hills Board Gamers Facebook Group

results.description:
In this free 75 minute live webinar you will be inspired and motivated to take care of yourself so that you can live well, and so that other beings and our biotic community may also flourish. Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, wildlife veterinarian and Unitarian Universalist minister, as well as co-director of One Earth Conservation, will be leading this interactive webinar where you will have the chance to slow down, reflect, share, and ask questions. LoraKim will offer readings, meditations, scientific information, and sample practices so that you are better able to nurture yourself and all of nature. You will learn of the five intelligences: Emotional, Social, Multispecies, Ecological, and Spiritual and how they can enrich life on this earth. We conclude with an overview of the full Nurture Nature Program and next steps for you, which we hope will include your participation in the course. The next steps include a two part webinar series on Emotional Intelligence, scheduled for the following two Saturdays, March 26th and April 2nd at 12 p.m. EDT.

Once you register for this free webinar we will send you information on how to link to the online webinar experience. You will need a computer with internet access, or a mobile phone with internet access. You can also join by direct phone, but you will not be able to see the visuals, which we can send to you as a separate file.

To register and for more information, go here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/introduction-to-nurturing-nature-yours-ours-theirs-the-earths-tickets-22062826508?aff=affiliate1
results.name: Introduction to Nurturing Nature: Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth's

results.description:
Learn about restorative organic juices to clean your body for a new season!

This is an opportunity to give your digestive system a break, learn new ways to tame your cravings, and discovers what works best for your unique body.

As always, juices are based on seasonal availability. After this workshop you can choose a juice plan that will work for you and pick up your daily juices at the yoga studio.

House of Juice is a “Garden to Cup” made in Brooklyn juicery and brewery. House of Juice crafts organic cold-pressed juices and smoothies along with small batch fermented probiotic sodas like jun and kombucha. House of Juice offers superfood boosters, shots and special drinks for nursing mothers.

House of Juice’s organic ingredients come from gardens in Brooklyn so, juices stay organic, local and seasonal. In this manner, House of Juice has found a way to be more local than everyone else by actually growing our produce. House of Juice literally serves “garden to cup.” Also, House of Juice is the first juice bar that will serve its own freshly brewed ciders, making House of Juice both a juicery and brewery.
results.name: Cleaning the Body for the Season

Hey Guys,

The 5v5 Coed Tournament is back this Spring, March 19th.


Team and free-agent registration is at: http://www.group-stage.com/1daytourny/

Note: You need to register with payment by Thurs March 17th. Only players registered and assigned a team in advance can play in the tournament.


It's World Cup format. All players receive team jerseys and post tournament drink specials in the LES! The Champions win trophies! Minimum 4 games so everyone gets plenty of game time.

DETAILS:

• Teams are 5v5, max roster 8 players


•  22min matches, unlimited subs

• Players receive GSF T-shirt


•  Finalists awarded trophies


•  2 female players required during matches


•  Drinks specials at a local bar!

REGISTRATION:


1. FREE AGENT: $35* Register here


2. TEAM: $250* Register here

Teams are confirmed once payment is received in full. Free-Agents that want to be on the same team as friends, just let us know in the comments section.


*Proceeds go toward the Green Shoots Kid's program. Programs starts April in Brooklyn - to volunteer as a coach or get involved send us a direct message.

RULES:

- Groups A & B, 4 teams in each. Like the World Cup group stage, top 2 teams progress to the next round. Other Teams play 3rd v 3rd and 4th v 4th match.

- Standard Tournament scoring (3 points for a win, 1 for a draw). If teams are tied on points, standings are decided by goal difference then goals scored.


- Players must be in proper soccer attire and team color, cleats are allowed on the turf field.

results.description:
Few phenomena in nature are as beautiful, intriguing and mesmerizing as the Northern Lights. In this workshop, astronomer and photographer Dr. William Gutsch will show and explain how explosive eruptions on the sun and holes in the sun’s atmosphere can lead to dazzling displays of the Northern and Southern Lights on earth.

He will also give tips on when and where to travel to see the aurora, as well as suggestions for choosing the right equipment to take the best still and time lapse images. Pictures from his recent trip to shoot the Northern Lights in the Arctic will be shown.

In addition, Dr. Gutsch will also speak about an upcoming photo opportunity of a lifetime: a Northern Lights 7-day Photo Adventure in Tromso, "The Aurora Capital of the World"!  Click here for more information about the adventure.

-----

A professional astronomer, producer and director, Dr. Gutsch was a long time Chairman of the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Science Editor for WABC and Special Science Correspondent for Good Morning America. In these and other capacities, he has written and produced numerous documentaries for television and large domed theaters across the US and around the world. He has lectured and led tours to all seven continents, has conducted professional photo shoots from the jungles of Central America to the temples of Bali and has directed numerous celebrities in New York, Hollywood, London and at Lucasfilms from Gregory Peck and Burt Lancaster to Captain Kirk, Mr. Spock, R2D2 and C-3P0.
results.name: *FREE RSVP* Stalking and Shooting the Northern Lights Seminar
