results.description:
Theme for March: "Things that Fly"

Bring a set you'd like to build with friends*, show something interesting you've already built (or pictures), or just bring yourself! Feel free to bring anything you like, but bonus points for bringing something that flies! Yup, we're hoping to see your planes, helicopters, and space ships. Flying dinosaurs too!

ACTIVITIES:
Build Contest - Using the bricks on hand at the meetup build something that flies and we'll vote for our favorite to win a small Lego set prize. Chris will be bringing some of his airport runway platforms so we'll be able to showcase our creations.

Free Build - As always, there will be a big pile of pieces for free building throughout the afternoon.

Additional Builds/Sharing TBD - based on what members bring*

* When you bring a set for shared building at the event, you are not donating it, but just enjoying building it with others. You take your set back home.

Location TBD in Midtown Manhattan.

Note on Fees:
We're charging a small fee so that we can get a better handle on attendance. We want to make sure that we have plenty of table space for everyone to build, but also hate to waste money on larger rooms for no-shows. Refunds available if you change your RSVP more than 36 hours in advance. Otherwise, we have an optional pay-what-you-can policy. Feel free to contribute (or not) via credit card here on Meetup or in cash at events. Lego can be an expensive hobby and we want this group to remain accessible to everyone. We welcome casual fans, serious AFOLs, and newbies alike.

Fees go towards snacks, room costs, Lego prizes, and meetup fees.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 102nd street and Amsterdam Ave. The entrance gate is located on west101st and Amsterdam ave. 

Directions: 1 train to 103rd St. Also, B or D trains to 103rd St stop

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: 

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
The terms “health” and “disease” seem to play an important role for both medical professionals and patients alike, at least at first blush. For medical professionals, the terms can be seen as being used to determine biological dysfunctions and suggest courses of treatment. For patients, determining whether something is a “disease” may guide them to seek out solutions from the medical establishment in the first place. Concepts of health and disease also seem to have normative import at both the personal and societal levels. At the personal level, these terms suggest whether or not one “should” seek solutions to a purported problem at all and whether people “should” be blamed for their maladies. At the societal level, labelling something as a disease can guide policy, funding, and insurance decisions.


But pinning down what is “health” and what is “disease” in the first place can be a tricky matter. While philosophers of medicine have a lot to say about this issue, during this meetup we will take a narrower but more unique approach by examining how two people with experience in medicine and the biological sciences approach these philosophical issues. The meetup will be facilitated by philosophy enthusiast and PharmD Gregory Lopez.

During the first hour of this meetup, we will discuss this paper by a respiratory clinician who takes a nominalist approach to health and disease, utilizing unique insights from his clinical experience combined with conceptual analysis to come up with a general theory of disease. He argues that the words “health” and “disease” name different things at different stages of medical inquiry and understanding.

During the second hour, we will discuss this paper by a neuroscientist who takes a quasi-eliminativist approach. He claims that while the concepts of “health” and “disease” can make sense in some circumstances, the concepts do not do as much work as philosophers of medicine think. Instead, many people much of the time could think more clearly about medical issues if they eliminated these concepts from their inquiries.

To prepare for the meetup, please read the two papers described above.
results.name: Meeting 34: What is Health and What is a Disease?

Another new idea!  Group chat by telephone!  

I am constantly trying to come up with new ideas for the group, and here's my latest.  If this turns out successfully, I will begin offering this for other languages too.  

Why by telephone:
a) it's convenient for attendees.
b) it is VERY good practice, because understanding telephone conversation (with no visual cue) is one of the most challenging of listening exercises.
c) you get to practice speaking French from wherever you are (as long as it's a quiet area).
d) limited to 6 attendees total, so you'll definitely get an opportunity to speak.

Once you register, I will provide the conference call number.

NOTE: The entire phone call from beginning to end will be in French.  

TOPICS: Please study up on and be prepared to discuss the following three topics:
a) The current economic situation in China.
b) The sport of bobsledding.
c) Your plans for this spring.


--Monroe

Hello New York City Event Planners! Thank you for checking out our meet up! We are currently in the process of starting an Event Planning Expo business and we are currently seeking businesses who will be willing to vendor for us. Whether you're already in business, just starting a business, or would like to promote it, all types are welcomed! Planning a wedding or event these days can be a nightmare! Especially when you don't know where to find event planners. You would have to call businesses, have them come to your home or office at a time thats never convenient, find people online without visual aids, etc. The whole idea of this business will be where event planners of all kind can all come together, set up a table, showcase their business, reveal samples and visual aids, hand out business cards, meet clients face-to-face, sell stuff and book events, all at once! We would like this Event Planning Expo to take place at a park in the spring and summer time and at a hotel banquet hall in the fall and winter. We are looking for the following: 

-Photographers

-DJs 

-Tent rentals 

-Limousine rentals

-Caterers (Sample and sell your own food)

-Magicians

-Candy Buffet Suppliers

-Balloon Suppliers/Balloonists

-Animal show businesses

-Inflatable rentals

...Anything Event Planning related!


Our goal for the Expos is to help other businesses promote their own, to make it convenient for people (guests who attend) to plan their own events and to also be a place where families and friends can come and have fun! The way you earn money is entirely up to you! Whether it's selling food, booking events with a down payment, selling bracelets for all day access to the moon bouncers for the kids, etc. We would like to hold meet ups at least once a month, so we will have more vendors at each Expo. results.description:
Videokaffe presents Para-sites & Proto-types, a participatory installation at Open Source Gallery.

Videokaffe is an art collective known for occupying spaces for intensive work periods and throughout March will harness their members’ skills and the surrounding’s materials to create artworks acutely engaged with their place at Open Source.  Para-sites & Proto-types will transform the gallery into a ‘science-garage-arcade’ using the space as a combination exhibition venue, cafeteria, and workshop open to the public.  Videokaffe will work on-site at the gallery, scouring and collecting from the local environment to create work by integrating found and recycled materials with ready-made components.  They will exhibit their methods of working, encouraging conversation with the public – and inviting interested viewers to participate in various aspects of the project.  

THIS IS A FREE EVENT; NO TICKET PURCHASE IS NECESSSARY.

Para-sites & Proto-types aims to build artwork uniquely formed from and with their environment by recycling objects and testing environmental possibilities.  Instead of installing finished work within the gallery, Para-sites & Proto-types will integrate art into the urban architecture surrounding Open Source, celebrating how art nurtures the environment and how the environment nurtures art.

Videokaffe is an international artist group with a background in visual arts, sound and engineering. It’s members are professionals in various forms of art and craft: sculpture, video production, boat building, clocksmithing and art education.

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". THERE IS NO NEED TO POST WHY YOU CAN'T MAKE THE EVENT. 

HAVE EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING. PLEASE DRESS PROPERLY FOR THE WINTER CONDITIONS.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will comment on some things (the architecture and social history of some of the buildings) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will be stopping at a number of points of interest. (IF YOU DON'T LIKE THIS STOPPING, THEN THIS WALK IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU.) This walk is about 2 1/2 to 3 miles and moderate paced. 

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John (the Event Host), who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo.

Description: This walk will focus on the poor people (particularly the Eastern European immigrant experience) during the Gilded Age and beyond from about 1870 to 1930.  We will discuss living in a cold-water flat; the money-saving party balcony on tenement buildings; the bank that fooled the poor immigrant population with its deceptive name; the New York Yankees' "dirty little secret"; the synagogue cleverly designed by Roman Catholic architects; the dumbbell structures with airshafts; the street that brought shame to the poor Lower East Side neighborhood; sleeping on the roof with your neighbors during a hot summer night; Friday morning's crowded "Pig Market"; the very unpleasant (but unavoidable) "school sink"; the really dirty job of the night soil men; the architectural styles of the Lower East Side tenement buildings; and wine "so thick you can almost cut it with a knife."

If we are able to, we might stop inside one or two old synagogues.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person. which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (after lunch) at 2:00 PM.

Meeting Place:  The meeting place is outside of the entrance to the New Museum, which is at 235 Bowery. Before the walk, restrooms are available on the lower level of the New Museum. During the walk, there will be limited places to stop for a restroom.

Transportation Options: Take the "F" subway train to 2nd Avenue (about 3 blocks away) or the No. 6 subway train to Spring Street (about 4 blocks away) or the "J" subway train to the Bowery (about 2 blocks away).

Finishing Time/Place: This walk will finish between 4:30 PM and 4:45 PM on East Houston Street and Norfolk Street.

Rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions or the forecast is for rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning. This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.

Below was children licking blocks of ice on a hot summer day. (Photo Bain News Service, July, 1912)

Below was newsgirls selling newspapers. (Photo Lewis Wickes Hine, May, 1910)

Below was newsboys, holding copies of  another Yiddish newspaper and waiting in front of 175 East Broadway at 1 A.M. for The Forward. (Photo Lewis Wickes Hine, March, 1913)

(Investigative photographer Lewis Wickes Hine documented children, particularly child labor.)

Below is a mural by Antonio "Chico" Garcia about the children of the Lower East Side neighborhood in recent years. This mural was painted sometime between 1998 and 2008. Many Lower East Side businesses have hired Antonio "Chico" Garcia to create storefront art and advertisements.
results.name: History of Poor People during the Gilded Age and Beyond Walk (Mar 20)

results.description:
This selection tied for second place in our reading poll. Historical fiction is indeed popular among us. 

Willie Sutton was born in the squalid Irish slums of Brooklyn, in the first year of the twentieth century, and came of age at a time when banks were out of control. If they weren't failing outright, causing countless Americans to lose their jobs and homes, they were being propped up with emergency bailouts. Trapped in a cycle of panics, depressions and soaring unemployment, Sutton saw only one way out, only one way to win the girl of his dreams.

So began the career of America's most successful bank robber. Over three decades Sutton became so good at breaking into banks, and such a master at breaking out of prisons, police called him one of the most dangerous men in New York, and the FBI put him on its first-ever Most Wanted List.

But the public rooted for Sutton. He never fired a shot, after all, and his victims were merely those bloodsucking banks. When he was finally caught for good in 1952, crowds surrounded the jail and chanted his name.

Blending vast research with vivid imagination, Pulitzer Prize winner J.R. Moehringer brings Willie Sutton blazing back to life. In Moehringer's retelling, it was more than poverty or rage at society that drove Sutton. It was one unforgettable woman. In all Sutton's crimes and confinements, his first love (and first accomplice) was never far from his thoughts. And when Sutton finally walked free - a surprise pardon on Christmas Eve, 1969 - he immediately set out to find her.

Poignant, comic, fast-paced and fact-studded, Sutton tells a story of economic pain that feels eerily modern, while unfolding a story of doomed love that is forever timeless.
results.name: "Sutton," by J.R. Moehringer

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
